title: Rock legend Jimmy Barnes takes to the stage in Sydney for his 'biggest headline tour this century'
text:
He is the legendary Scottish-Australian rocker who is currently on his 'biggest headline tour this century'.

And musical icon Jimmy Barnes certainly put on a show on Saturday night, as he took to the stage at the famous Hordern Pavilion in Moore Park, Sydney.

The 63-year-old appeared in high spirits as he brought the stage to life with his high-energy performance, blasting out hits such Working Class Man and Lay Down Your Guns.

He's still got it! Musical legend Jimmy Barnes certainly put on a show on Saturday night, as he graced the stage at the Hordern Pavilion in Sydney

On stage, Jimmy kept his ensemble simple - sporting some black jeans and and smart black shirt, which he undid a few times to unleash his chest underneath.

As he grabbed on to the microphone, Jimmy screamed the lyrics out passionately - with his love for performing clear for all to see.

So far, his 'Shutting Down Your Town' tour has gone down a treat with audiences, with one fan posting on Instagram: 'This dude still got it... it was epic.'

'It was epic'! Fans of the rocker admitted that despite decades in the business, his voice is still as sensational as ever

Flashing the chest! Jimmy kept his ensemble simple - sporting some black jeans and and smart black shirt, which he undid a few times to unleash his chest hair underneath

'Fantastic show Jimmy loved the old and new music'! Jimmy's fans took to social media to share their thoughts on his new performance

'Fantastic show Jimmy loved the old and new music!' a second wrote, while a third added: 'Awesome show. Thanks for letting us enjoy such a night with you and your family. Been a fan for years you rock.'

Earlier in the year, Jimmy opened up about his battle with addictions in a candid interview.

He confirmed he only takes to the stage under the influence of honey and water, after learning to cope with his demons.

Therapy: Jimmy says asking for help and seeing a therapist has helped him in his battle with addiction

Opening up: Jimmy spoke out about his battle with addictions in a candid interview earlier in the year

'I never drink before or during the shows,' he told The Weekend Australian, adding the only alcoholic beverages in his dressing room are for his band.

'I drink honey and hot water - it's really good.'

Jimmy has admitted in recent years to trying take his own life in an Auckland hotel room in 2012.

But after spending the best part of the last decade in therapy, the singer admits he is much more able to control his mental struggles.

'I think I'm singing better because of it (therapy) - it's something I can harness rather than be led by,' he said.
